title: How to Make Cornish Conger Cakes

steps.headline: Prepare either the rocks or the grill by rubbing down the cooking surface  with mutton fat or butter.
Start cooking the conger meat until it is soft and flaky.
steps.description: Remove it from the heat and let it cool.

steps.headline: Beat the eggs.
steps.description: Add the cooled conger meat and break it down so that you have a fishy egg pulp. If you want to add herbs or vegetables, now is the time to add them.

steps.headline: Mix in most of the oats.
steps.description: Your mixture should be thick enough to form patties. If not, add more oats, saving some for sprinkles.

steps.headline: Form the mixture into patties, being sure to squeeze any excess fluid from them.
steps.description: You're looking at the same size as a cookie, only fatter and not as wide.

steps.headline: Dust the excess oats over the patties.
steps.description: They'll stop your fish cakes from sticking.

steps.headline: Press the patties down onto your heated rock or grill.
steps.description: With the grill you'll need to turn them occasionally.

steps.headline: Notice that once  the cakes are fairly hard, they're ready.
steps.description: You should have nice soft  juicy centers and hard durable surfaces - almost crunchy but not quite. If you cooked them on the rocks, they should have nice distinctive bases! They might also pick up a natural salty flavour.

text: Prepare either the rocks or the grill by rubbing down the cooking surface  with mutton fat or butter.  Start cooking the conger meat until it is soft and flaky. Remove it from the heat and let it cool. Beat the eggs. Add the cooled conger meat and break it down so that you have a fishy egg pulp. If you want to add herbs or vegetables, now is the time to add them. Mix in most of the oats. Your mixture should be thick enough to form patties. If not, add more oats, saving some for sprinkles. Form the mixture into patties, being sure to squeeze any excess fluid from them. You're looking at the same size as a cookie, only fatter and not as wide. Dust the excess oats over the patties. They'll stop your fish cakes from sticking. Press the patties down onto your heated rock or grill. With the grill you'll need to turn them occasionally. Notice that once  the cakes are fairly hard, they're ready. You should have nice soft  juicy centers and hard durable surfaces - almost crunchy but not quite. If you cooked them on the rocks, they should have nice distinctive bases! They might also pick up a natural salty flavour. Finished.
